table.head: GORDON COLLEGE.
table.p: The day after oor visit to Omdarman, tbp Press party and the Legislative Councillor.- paid a visit to the Gordon College. In mam ways this was the most interesting sight rf all. The olose attention paid by the boys, Arabs. Blaoks, Berberines and mixed races, to their teachers, their evident intelligence and eager- ness to learn, and tbeir bearing and discipline, delighted everybody, and the members of the Legislative Council were load in their praise of the College. The system of teaching the currioalom of the various olassee, and the num- ber, extraction,and aptitudes of the pupils most be treated separately and at length ; for the present I need only say that the object of the Gordon College i« to train young Sudanese to be of use to the Government and to the com- munity, whether they afterwards become kadi«, schoolmasters or artisans. andthrtthe founders of the College forget that such an institution set down in the midst of a barbarous and newly conquered country had to have small beginnings. The College was certainly in its beginnings a primary school for black boys—it is difficult to see how it oould have been anything else, for whatever the capabilities of the Sudanese youths for absorbing higher or even secondary educa- tion without any tiresome primary training, these do not spring up from the soil, and I believe that European educational systems are based without exception on a course of pri- mary education, whioh is generally supposed to be a necessary preliminary to more advanced study. The chief event in the history of the Gordon College during 1905 was the creation of an Upper School, which already oounts 15 pupils. This may not seem an immense nrm- her, but education was to put it mildly— primitive at the time of th9 reoonqnest, and Upper Schools are not oreated in a day. Tb« time, however, oame when its oreation was considered feasible, and Mr.Currie the Director of Education in the Sadan, having obtained the fundi, decided to oonsult the principal officials of the Technical Departments efrthe Sadan Government, vis, the Director of Works, the Director of Surveys, and ihe Director General cf Irrigation, with a view to learning tbeir opinions as to the training most required in the rew Upper School, and as to what type of employ^ would be most useful to the Government. The following reply from Mr. Dupuis, the Inspector General (f Irrigatirn in the Sudan deserves special attention by all who are interested in the spread of education not in the Sadan oi ly, bnt in all backward eonitries in the East. The principles it lays dc wn for the training of engineers are fqaally applicable in Persia, Mesopotamia and the central Sudan, and the‘future organisers of higher technical education in those regions will doubtless profit by the results attained at the Gordon Collepe. “Concerning the training of engineers and surveyorsIf all or even some of th* large works contemplated in connection with the training of the Nile and Irrigation in the Sudan are ever carried out, of which, I think there oan hardly be any dnubt. there most be an enormous deman i for men wfth at leant an elementary knowledge of surveying, land measuring and simple oonstruotion. The convenience and economy of being able to obtain suoh men locally, instead of hwing to tempt them away from Egypt by the offer of salaries often out of all proportion to their sooial standing and qualifications, would be immense, and theadvan'age to anew country like the Sudan of the oreation of a class with some engineering trailing oould not but be very great. The special kind of qualification for which a demand would arise on the undertaking of sooh works as are contemplated would ba those that woald fit a man to lay out lines, measure land area®, preoare simple plans, supervise earth works, lime and brick burning, and the construction of simple masonary works. An elemerita’y knowledge of how. to keen accounts in any simple and oomprebensibl form, would be a most rsetul additional quali- fication. Imagine the case of the consfruotion of a large canal system say in the Ghezira; the first step would be the retting out of the lines of the oanals, and the demarcation and expropriation tf the areas of laud they would occupy ; these lires would extend certainly over hundreds,and probably over thousands of kilometres. The next step would be the ex^ontion of th; necessary earthwork over there lines, an im mense business, and by no means so a mple a- is generally assumed* but one in whioh the presence of a capable 4upeivi<or can just m^k^ all the difference between the fini-hed work and strength, or being a permanent eyesore and eonree of trouble. Simultaneously with the earthwork a v*ry large number of bridges, regulators^ onlverts rest-hooBes, shelter-huts, e’e wonld be requir- ed : some of these works would nccef-snril require the presence rf tul’y trained engineer- of some experience ; hut for the innnmerab'e petty works an almost unlimited demand f>* cheap but trustworthy supervision would arisp. A very useful qua’ification wonld be a knowledge of lime and brick burning, w»tH Heas as to what constitutes suitable limesfone and briok eirth. where they are generally to be foand, and how to set about converting the crude pridnot into the finished article. In gnperv sing any snnh wo»k it would be necessary or derirable to kepp a running account (if expenditure; and for this an elementary knowledge of acoount keeping would be nseful. A very large demard for rongh but efficient temporary shelter huts and stoTe-hauses, almost always arisen in the early stage ol large under- takings ; and men with an intelligent eye for "he application of locally available material (generally mnd, grass, and in'erior timber) for fhe construction of such buildings, are of great use. So far I have been considering tfie use of suoh men regarded as overseers or supervisors, and working as subordinate employes in a 1-yge organi-ed staff of engineers ; but they would be at least equally nseful as petty con- tractors or gangers working at “ piece work,” •ndeed.the line dividing the temporarily engag- ed overseer on small pay from the petty con- tractor, often becomes very fine indeed. I think I have ssid enough to show the nature tf work f r which men of the most elementary qualifications are required, bdt if you are prepared to go further, there is nothing to prevent suoh meu being trained and educat- ed into fully qualified engineers. For this course^ «he first necessity is deeper knowledge of mathematics, and a cultivated reasoning power, to permit of the formation of intelligent forecasts of the probable course of events under given conditions. The nse of the level is a more or ISRS me- chanical operation, and might easily acquired and accurately practised by men of the first cla-s, without their quite understanding its inner bearings, and it is a qualification of the ntmost value ; but I should not expeot reliable results from the use of a theodolite by a man of limited mathematical attainments; more- over. the use (f the theodolite is comparatively restrict. I have therefore divided the snbjeots in which training might in my opinion be attempted, into two classes, which I denote “sub-overseers” and engineers”, olassed respectively after an old Indian clss^ifiobtion. div.title: SiCiLY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio- R* battino Co.’s steamers which leave Alex- andria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the mo t charm- jng and popular places on the island. G*auli• i is he station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.c. 212, when Archimedes was slain his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was onoe an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with abo t 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Gi ivannia degli Eremiti with its picturesq'-e cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit
div.title: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday dunng the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days. NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-R* battino Co.’s steam- ers, which leave (Lilly. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay— Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive tool will take you on to Capri. From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here. Leaving the Eternal City with mnoh regret, a railway journey qf'five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its s -rroundiDg country, m Florence iteelf the churches and galleries are of absorbing inte- rest, whilst the local promenades and excur- sions should not be omitted. The Caseins is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florenoe, whilst the Vials dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful exenrsiop outside Florence is that te Vailom- brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thenoe by cog- wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view. PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset. yiAREGGIQ. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near fisa and on the main line irem Rome to Genoa- It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.
div.title: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: QFNOA (La Soper ba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer. The patriarchal home of Italy’s most an- eient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands j of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa, j Then there are the superbly decorated medie- val churches containing exquisite marble oolumns and historical paintings, and the in- comparable Campo Santo filled with its won derful tombs. From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail. MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the to r of the Lakes. The j Cathedral is tne principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public crardens and the monu- mental cemetery are also worth a visit. Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and-a- halt from Milan is SALSOMAG- GIORE. a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Dornno and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.
div.title: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as “A cluster of delights and grandeurs.” LUGANO is some 20 miles from Gomo and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charm- ingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Are1 nd it rise M. San Salvatore, M, de Caprinoand M. Generoso. LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minntes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town,is worth a visit, as it contains interest- ing paintings, “Entombment,” by Ciseri, and ‘The Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion. LUCERNE.—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rtgi and PHatne and the snow-clad Alps, In pd around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Luoerne bv boat, rail, etc., are very numerous. The Like of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Riot, Pilatus, Bur gen stock and Sonnenberq needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake oan he made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip frcgpa Lucerne to Ffaelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature BRUNNEN', charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brennen to Fluelen runs the famous Axestram. A delightful excursion from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about X hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest^ and from the Santis to the Matteriw•*. THE BERNESE OBERLAN1).—INTER- LAKEN a favourite summer resort and the beet oentre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trvmmelbach and Staubboch. Then also the glaciers of Grindehvald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed. CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.
div.title: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alex- andria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co. If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be presen at the dancing on the Easter T« esday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens. It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
